Brazil’s political upheaval enters a critical phase today, when the centrist Party of the Brazilian Democratic Movement will formally break with the president, depriving her of 69 votes out of 513 in Congress’s lower house. Ms Rousseff needs 172 to fend off impeachment—ostensibly over dodgy government accounting, but really over sleaze and economic incompetence. She has 110-odd in the bag. The PMDB’s departure vacates seven ministries, which her emissaries are offering to smaller parties in exchange for loyalty. Michel Temer, the PMDB boss, who as vice-president takes over if deputies vote to send impeachment proceedings to the Senate for trial, has also been busy over Easter, promising posts in his own putative administration. Tomorrow the Supreme Court weighs in: a procedural decision may hint whether it thinks Ms Rousseff tried to obstruct a corruption probe into prominent figures from her Workers’ Party. An unfavourable ruling would weaken her further—possibly fatally

Ms. Rousseff described the efforts to remove her from office as “lacking legal foundations,” and she lashed out at Eduardo Cunha, the speaker of the lower house of Congress, who has been plagued with scandals of his own. Ms. Rousseff said that Mr. Cunha put impeachment proceedings into motion as a way of deflecting attention from his own legal troubles over charges of bribery and money laundering. “Why do they want me to resign?” Ms. Rousseff, Brazil’s first female president, asked in the interview. “Because I’m a woman, fragile. The Swiss accounts would just be a portion of the grease payments to the politicians, which themselves only represent a tiny fraction of the total amount siphoned out of Petrobas and similar Brazilian entities. While the Brazilian investigators must of course get their own house in order first by pursuing the politicians and local facilitators, it will be interesting to see how far they pursue the corporations that gained most from the looting of the Brazilian state enterprises. While the unwinding of these contracts will take time, they are almost certain to obtain recovery plus penalties. The amounts are enormous. Brazil would be well-advised to forgo the mass sale of assets they are currently undertaking and instead issue a special set of bonds backed by the funds recoverable under the to-be-unwound overbilled Petrobas and other state entity contracts. In addition, just as there were facilitators on the inside, an operation of this magnitude required facilitators on the outside. It will be interesting to learn of these global facilitators that orchestrated the corporate looting of the Brazilian enterprises. As a first approximation, I think it would be reasonable to assume that the entire "excess" debt incurred by these enterprises is a fair representation of the magnitude of the looting. Brazil state enterprises were systematically looted, and while to the average Brazilian "Fora Dilma" may be all that matters, the far larger and more interesting story is the global looting of Brazil. We know who was paymaster for the politicians. We know who coordinated the overbilled contracts from the inside. We know who oversaw the players on the inside. We do not yet know who coordinated the contracts on the outside (there is no way the volume of such over-billed contracts were the results of hundreds of vendors spontaneously crafting thousands of illegal contracts). We also do not yet know who oversaw the players on the outside.

On Friday the clock started ticking for Dilma Rousseff. Congress’s lower house voted to start impeachment proceedings against the president, who has until early April to present her defence against charges of accounting trickery. Days earlier millions marched demanding her fall. Last week the Bar Association became the latest body to back the protesters. Ms Rousseff will be hoping that her 300,000-odd supporters who turned out on March 18th will sway at least 172 out of 513 deputies—the number she needs to avert trial by the Senate. Last week she appointed as chief of staff Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, her wily predecessor, to help cajole congressmen. But the move was blocked by a Supreme Court judge, who argued that its purpose was to shield Lula from a corruption probe. The government is appealing to the full tribunal, which won’t meet for another week. A tense Easter beckons

"But while many Brazilians initially welcomed {Judge} Moro’s fearless work {pursuing the Petrobras scandal} , there is increasing unease at both the methods and targets of his inquiry. Much of this testimony has then been leaked to Brazil’s press, which is overwhelmingly hostile to the ruling Workers’ party.

"Max Marcel, 32, a teacher from Ceilândia, a working-class district on the outskirts of Brasília, echoed the sentiments of many. “We are not going to allow a coup,” he said. “The people who want impeachment are those sections of the Brazilian elite who were not able to win at the urns and now want to carry out a judicial and media coup.”

There is evidence of massive campaign violations, confirmation of the kickbacks that helped convict Odebrecht, and allegations of government meddling in the courts. Yesterday’s wiretapped conversation with Lula also puts Rousseff in an unpalatable position, but the presidential palace has claimed that there was good justification for the conversation. Because of the legitimacy concerns noted above, none of these, as yet, seems sufficient to generate the momentum needed in the final push for impeachment, especially in the context of a rudderless, divided, and increasingly discredited opposition,” writes CFR's Matthew Taylor. Here's a good summary of the process that must be followed: "For the process to move forward, the lower house has to create a special impeachment committee comprised of representatives from all political parties to evaluate and recommend whether to accept the allegations made against the president. Parties must form the committee, which will have as many as 66 members. The president has 10 sessions to defend herself before the committee, which then has at least five sessions to make a recommendation." http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-08/impeaching-a-brazilian-president-is-complicated-a-quick-guide That committee was formed today. There are more steps beyond that, and it's not exactly certain at what point this question will result in a "yes", however the required 10 sessions alone almost certainly put us past April 1.

Even though it seems likely that Dilma will be forced out of office, this will not happen before April 1st. In Brazil’s history, the previous impeachment attempt in 1992 (of Collor) took several months to be brought to the Senate (from the Chamber of Deputies). Even after impeachment has been brought to the Senate, Collor did not resign until two-three months after the start of the Senate proceedings. Since the lower house has not yet impeached Dilma, it is extremely unlikely that Dilma will resign or be impeached before the deadline.

"This is called “coalitional presidentialism”. To work properly, it relies on the president’s various informal and formal governing powers. The president can issue provisional measures (executive decrees) when a congressional majority for a bill is not assured. She can offer coalition partners ministries (sometimes with the power to appoint hundreds of their subordinates in the ministry), and she can direct federal spending in ways that benefit political partners. But the system is now in crisis. While the government has a majority in the Senate, Rousseff has been unable to cobble together a working majority in the lower house of Congress, where she is facing a showdown.

SÃO PAULO—A Brazilian judge on Tuesday sentenced Marcelo Odebrecht, the former chief executive officer of South America’s biggest construction company, to 19 years in prison for his involvement in a sprawling corruption scandal centered on Brazil’s state oil company, Petrobras.
Mr. Odebrecht’s sentencing comes amidst an explosive month in Brazilian politics that is threatening to engulf the leftist government of President Dilma Rousseff.
Ms. Rousseff hasn’t been implicated in the sprawling corruption investigation at Petróleo Brasileiro SA, as the oil company is officially known, and has denied knowledge of the graft ring. But the scandal has moved ever closer to her door as one high-profile figure after another has been ensnared in the probe.

In reviewing some history that leads up to where we are now with this question, it seems that, at least in terms of the broadest allegations, there is nothing new that was not already foreshadowed years ago when the Petrobas scandal first broke. Even then, from its very inception, there were signs that it would lead directly to Lula and Dilma. Here we are now, three years later, and they're still around. This makes a strong argument for them, or at least Dilma, "being around" for a lot longer, well beyond the horizon of this question. In thinking about an inspiring article provided by @000, however, I am also thinking that we shall begin to see a new set of social phenomena that may not yet have been recognized or articulated. It may not occur in Brazil, or maybe it will. It can be generally described as an awakening to the notion that: "Error had been routed, and now science could advance." I'm thinking it's a notion, still formative, seeking representation (expression) through communicative symbols. Maybe it will blossom in Brazil this week. It's a notion that, once embodied, will cause even the most ardent communist worker to pause, reflect, and say: "They have dragged this country through three years of total crap and they were aware of the "error" the entire time." Again, think about this. An "error" was alleged three years ago. An epistemological error. Those in the position to correct this error remained silent, causing millions to remain in error, for three years. Maybe I am wrong, and this is not a new element in the current psyche, or not a matured element, or neither in Brazil. It probably won't happen this week. It hasn't happened for three years. I'm thinking it is a possibility though; a form of overcoming politics with science. Edit: A tenuous connection to the Presidential Election in the United States.

Politicians tend to wait until the last moment to jump just before being pushed. Three weeks may be a long time in the news cycle, but if a politician/government-official is playing for time (in the hopes that public interest will fade/divert and that by remaining in office they will be able to protect themselves or negotiate a favorable exit from a stronger position), odds are positive that they can do so. Impeachment is also a legal process, with associated rights and procedures, and therefore will not happen over night. In the case of second and third world countries, other power centers that would not be taken into account during normal times in first world countries also have to be considered, like the military.  In addition, many individuals in the power centers are also focused on protecting themselves due to the investigations and as long as the justice system is not seen as corruptible in cases of major figure investigation/prosecution, this should have a restraining influence on big, political maneuvers by both sides.  For the opposition, given the widespread nature of the investigations, keeping pressure on and hoping for further opponents to be implicated brings benefit. Moving quickly may bring satisfaction, but one assumes that the power centers in the opposition party have a sense of the strategic as well as the tactical. In conclusion, the pattern for such situations tends to follow a pattern of delay/obfuscate/placate/compromise/etc until a sufficient number of the real power players decides that it is necessary for the individual to resign and forces the issue (i.e. pushes).

The president has managed to delay this long. Regardless of developments in his probability of EVENTUALLY being impeached, the proceedings have not even begin to proceed against him. Abdication is even less unlikely. Unless the House of Representatives decides to speed up significantly, highly unlikely.

Impeachment proceedings for Dilma Rousseff began in December of 2015. There has been some substantial progress with the proceedings since then, and Barclays’ Bruno Rovai wrote to clients that Rousseff’s chances of impeachment were rising once again. Over the last week her campaign manager was arrested over illegal payments received in his party’s offshore accounts. Also Rousseff’s own party is disagreeing with her economic agenda, and social movements have started showing signs of not approving of her agenda (there are protests scheduled for March 13). Rousseff’s approval rating is 11, down from 12% in December. Rovai personally believes that “the longer the impeachment process lies in the House of Representatives, the higher the likelihood that it will be approved.” Therefore it seems like Rousseff will be impeached eventually, just not necessarily within the month. The House of Representatives has been very slow-moving up to this point, therefore I do not think that there will be a mad rush to impeach her as soon as possible.

http://www.americasquarterly.org/content/cassacao-impeachment-and-brazils-dilma-rousseff-guide "Just when Brazil’s President Dilma Rousseff seemed to be clearing the threat of impeachment, another challenge to her presidency is gaining momentum. The arrest of one of Rousseff’s top political advisers on allegations he received $7.5 million in illicit funds has fueled speculation that the government could be toppled by cassação, or the judicial revocation of Rousseff’s presidential mandate. "Unlike impeachment,. . .  the decision to rule on cassação is up to the Tribunal Superior Eleitoral (TSE), Brazil’s electoral court. If invoked, it would oust both Rousseff and Vice President Michel Temer, leaving House Speaker Eduardo Cunha as interim president until a new popular election could be held. "The TSE since October has been investigating whether Rousseff’s 2014 reelection campaign was funded with illicit money, which would be grounds for cassação. But the February 23 arrest of João Santana, a former Workers' Party (PT) treasurer who orchestrated Rousseff’s successful presidential campaigns in 2010 and 2014, raised the possibility for the first time that the TSE investigation could incorporate evidence collected under the wide-reaching Operação Lava Jato (“Operation Car Wash”) federal investigation into graft at Petrobras. “If there is a connection between the election of Rousseff and Lava Jato, that would implode the government,” said Gabriel Petrus, a political consultant at Brasilia-based Barral M Jorge & Associates who served as an adviser to Rousseff's previous chief of staff. At the very least, he added, Santana’s arrest will raise the political thermometer and revive talk of impeachment proceedings.
. . . 
"While police said Santana’s arrest is not part of an investigation into illicit campaign finance, it does have the “potential to give more robustness to allegations that [Rousseff’s] campaign violated campaign finance law,” according to the Washington-based political risk consultancy Eurasia Group. If the money turns out to have been an illicit campaign donation to Rousseff and the PT, it would violate electoral transparency regulations, break rules against foreign financing of elections and, most alarmingly, suggest that she won election with funds skimmed from Petrobras contracts. “We now attribute equal weight between a scenario where new elections are called this year (20 percent), and one in which Rousseff is impeached and Vice President Michel Temer finishes her term,” Eurasia analysts said in a February 22 research note, giving a 40 percent probability to Rousseff not finishing her term. "The TSE is composed of seven judges, with some seen as eager to investigate allegations filed by the opposition Brazilian Social Democracy Party (PSDB) . . . Just as a simple majority of TSE judges could open the hearings, so can a simple majority enforce cassação. "Independent of the TSE’s activities, Congress in early December opened impeachment proceedings based on accusations Rousseff’s government broke fiscal responsibility laws. The proceedings, which stalled in mid-December, are expected to restart in late March after the Supreme Court makes a final ruling on how the House is to choose its 65-person impeachment committee. "Thiago de Aragão, director of strategy for Brasilia-based political consultancy Arko Advice, says that risk of impeachment is still higher than risk of cassação, which is a much slower-moving judicial process that could see repeated legal appeals. Rousseff has so far maintained a coalition to block impeachment, but more of her public and political support will take a hit from Santana’s arrest.
. . . 
“We’re on the border of changing eras in Brazil,” said Aragão. “Until recently, anyone involved in the PT was immune. Now people are discovering that it’s not like this. The times are changing.”
~~~~~~~

https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/poder/2016/02/1743480-pmdb-volta-a-considerar-impeachment-apos-prisao-de-santana.shtml&prev=search * Assuming that Reuters has indeed adopted this policy, they could be creating a data set of forecaster success. I wonder if they are implementing these additional steps. I also wonder if they have conducted any consumer research on how readers understand and utilize such estimates. Also, do they affect any aspect of story "sentiment" compared to word estimates? Again, there is the potential consumer benefit (presumably more accurate forecasts, more precise communication of forecast meaning), as well as the potential down-the-road benefits of forecaster evaluation. I note that this particular forecaster estimated a 55% chance.** Do such cautious forecasts diminish the value of the story? Perhaps it would depend on for whom, and how, "value" is defined. There are a lot of trade-offs here: forecaster accountability. sterile numbers, lack of emotive words for propaganda appeal, etc. All things considered, it seems to me, at least as far as I've considered it in the time in which I've observed it, to be a positive change that should bring multiple benefits to numerous parties. ** As I think about it, I wonder if there is not one aspect of probabilistic estimates that has perhaps not been sufficiently addressed. That is, the unsophistication of the average user of such forecasts. There is, to some degree, a cognitive burden of sorts placed upon the consumer of such forecasts. I am not saying that this is bad, only that it is there. I am of the opinion that for the average user of forecasts to obtain the intended full benefits of a numerical probabilistic forecast, they must, to some extent at least, perform a sort of reverse-engineering on the logic that the forecaster used to construct the forecast. This reverse-engineering becomes a new potential source of error. What is required is for the consumer to first undertake a step where, all things considered, they develop their own forecast. Then, the value of the numerical forecast becomes apparent in the difference between consumer forecast and forecaster estimate. If the consumer fails to properly take the initial step, the estimate may have an emotive flatness that it does not deserve, so to speak. Consider the 55% estimate of the pundit in the Reuters story. What does this 55% mean to the consumer? My point is that for it to have the intended emotive effect, the consumer must first have some appreciation for the assumed "base rate" that the forecaster is employing. Am I wrong to think that most consumers approach a generic odds with a base rate assumption of 50%? (^1) That is, that any and all events are as equally likely to occur as not? I know this is naive, but one needs to start somewhere. In the Reuters example, the pundit "gave Rousseff a 55 percent chance of serving out her term through 2018." A required first step by the consumer would be to perform their own estimate of the estimate of the base rate, or alternatively, and less comparable class/statistical, the "non-intervened-upon-normal-causal-trajectory." Although simple, I am uncertain if most consumers take even this brief time to perform this task. If they would, perhaps they might come up with a "non-intervened-upon-normal-causal-trajectory" of near 100% for "Rouseff ... serving out her term through 2018," in which case the forecasters estimate of 55% is an absolute  difference of 45%, and that seems significant. But if they skip that step, and naively approach the odds as a random 50:50 event, as I myself admittedly did upon first reading, 55%-50%=5% doesn't seem that significant at all. A related aspect is that very often consumers are interested in the marginal effect of a particular intervention or set of interventions. In this Reuters/Rouseff example the "non-intervened-upon-normal-causal-trajectory" estimate of 100% neglects the "normal" interventions (such as natural or accidental death). The more these "natural" (unspecified) interventions add up, the "value" between a forecast and the base-rate diminishes, and it's more difficult (takes more work) to distill the value of any specific intervention under discussion, so to speak. That is, the "story" is typically motivated by the idea that "this particular intervention X" will change the "non-intervened-upon-normal-causal-trajectory" to such an extent that you, the consumer, should care about it. So, if the writer of the story wants to initiate an emotional response, words may still be best. If the writer of the story is willing to allow the consumer to undertake their own framing of the forecast and generate their own emotional response, the numerical forecast might be best. I don't know. Just thinking on some of these things out loud ... (^1): I am pleased to report that my intuitive notion was correct: "[A] common bias in which individuals default to 50/50 assessments when presented with complex situations, regardless of how well that stance fits with the evidence at hand." (from the Friedman/Zeckhauser paper, which I linked to first without reading.) Also see pg, 21 of this article for a concise explanation of the difference between predicting outcomes and assessing probabilities. (Are we all assessing probabilities of the same outcomes?)

What's becoming ever more clear in this Petrobas / Rousseff scandal is that the corruption: a) has been going for a very long-time across multiple administrations, and b) that it was seemingly "brought into" Brazil in some fashion. That is, it is not the result of a scheme that spontaneously created itself out of some random collection of transactions and indigenous individuals. It is far too comprehensive and inter-connected for that. It has individuals participating in activities that are out of the realm of their personal expertise. Many, many people performing functions, yet none seemingly sophisticated or capable enough to organize those functions. So I'm beginning to think the Brazilian thing tied into a pre-existing international network rather than just mushrooming from any set of internal schemes. These participants have been taught how to engage in such interrelated complexity on a massive scale. I haven't followed the scandal in detail at all really, so I do not know, but it's beginning to smell that way. I'll be curious to learn if this recent Santana catch is just another role participant, or more of an overall organizer.

This is not a prediction update, since I kept my previous estimate of 3%: I just want to remark that there is an alternative scenario gaining momentum, that could lead to President Rouseeff leaving office: campaign contestation ('impugnação' in Portuguese). This is not the same as resignation neither impeachment. Resignation would require President Rousseff choosing to leave office; Impeachment would require both Parlament Houses to agree that President Rousseff should indeed leave office; 'Impugnação de Campanha' or campaign contestation would require the Highest Electoral Court (TSE - Tribunal Superior Eleitoral) to agree that her campaign was improperly conducted. With the provisional arrest of João Santana, who was President Rousseff's campaign manager in 2010 and 2014 and also Lula's in 2006, it seems that part of the money illegally extracted from Petrobras was employed in President Rousseff's last campaign, and possibly in campaigns of some of her allies.
At this point in time, given the overall fragility of Parlament Houses and popular unrest, it seems to me that 'impugnação' became more feasible. And, if Parlament Reps are seeing things the way I described, I bet they would be less motivated to risk their public positions to pursue Rousseff's impeachment. I will wait to see if there are any signs of this 'sudden unwillingness' emerging among Parlament Reps before I get it reflected in my forecast.

Impeachment is more political than anything, so probabilities should be counted based on political factors. The factors I have included are:
•	Support in the Senate for the Government (Excluding the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, since their representative has brought up the charges in the Chamber of Representatives)
•	Support  in the Chamber of Representatives for the Government (Excluding the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party)
•	Rousseff’s current popularity (representatives can change their support based on increase or decrease in Rousseff’s general popularity) I created simulations for the number of votes for impeachment in the Senate and Chamber (weighting the Senate heavier since the Brazilian Supreme Court expanded the authority of the Senate in December 2015. This gave an overall probability that Rousseff’s impeachment would have resulted in the removal of Rousseff (or her stepping down because she knew she wouldn’t win)--20 percent. I took this to mean that this was the probability within a year. Dividing that by 12 would give a probability per month. Since one month was left before the close of the question, I took that to be a 1.7% chance of her removal. The next step was to factor her support (or rather lack of). Dilma Rousseff in December 2015 had a 65% negative rating.  Taking the chance of removal as a Bayesian Prior and the negative rating as the conditional probability, I got a 3% probability. Switching the prior and conditional would only give a 1% change to 4%.

I believe President Rousseff will resign if a) Brazilians go to the streets, in massive nonpartisan demonstrations; b) her political base, today reduced to the Workers' Party (PT - Partido dos Trabalhadores), withdraws its support. I estimate her resignation as very improbable because PT would hardly turn their back on her: that would cost them their entire political capital and such "day-after", "no-shield" scenario, I guess, they cannot afford*. However, paths leading to impeachment seem more feasible to me. One of them contingent on following narrative: a) Brazilians go to the streets in massive nonpartisan demonstrations against corruption scandals involving high ranks of the government and their allies, and the strong recession that stroke Brazil in 2015. This would promote the impeachment process already in Congress. b) More high-ranking government officials or allies are arrested, as happened in November 25th, 2015, when Senator Delcídio Amaral (PT-MS) was arrested by interfering with Lava Jato -- an ongoing, high profile corruption investigation led by federal prosecutors. I assess that that would considerably refrain their popular base from organising demonstrations in support of President Rousseff. c) Lula (ex-president, public leader, and “éminence grise”) or his heirs are directly implicated by ongoing investigations (Atibaia farm case, Guarujá triplex apartment case, LFT Sport Marketing case, among many others), who have accumulated an impressive amount of wealth after PT coming to power. That, too, would considerably inhibit popular demonstrations in support of President Rousseff. d) The Lower House (Câmara dos Deputados, analogue of the US House of Representatives) expedites the impeachment process submitted to their evaluation in December 2nd, 2015, recommending the Higher House to proceed with President Rousseff's impeachment** under the legal grounds that her administration severely violated fiscal austerity laws. Since the impeachment process under the Brazilian law is predominantly a political one, public support seems more critical than having a sound legal claim. e) The Higher House (Senado Federal, analogue of the US Senate) endorses the Lower House recommendation and proceeds to approve the impeachment. To this almost incredible narrative, I will add one known fact: the next massive popular demonstration against President Rousseff has been scheduled to March 13th. Since this is step 1 of 5 in that loony narrative I happen to believe in, I deem the event “Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff impeached before 1 April 2016” as highly improbable. * PT cannot afford "day-after" scenario because they fear they would have hard times trying to find new jobs -- both low and high ranks, because private capital owners find their incompetence blatant, and workers lost their respect in them. And they cannot afford the "no-shield" scenario because they fear many of them (low and high ranks) would have their financial lives scrutinised by federal authorities once PT is no longer in power. ** House of Representatives recommending approval of the impeachment process, I believe, is not much contingent on having Deputado (Representative) Eduardo Cunha as President of the House, since he may loose this chair in a short timeframe because of implications of corruption raised by federal prosecutors under Lava Jato. COMMENT:  This is why I think Rousseff won't survive to the end of her term.  However, I think she'll survive until April Fool's Day because of the complexities of the impeachment process and the powers she has to throw monkey wrenches in the works to delay it.

An impeachment or resignation by Rouseff is within the realm of possibility before the end of her term, but highly unlikely before April 1st (7 weeks from now). The Brazilian Constitution specifies that a maximum of 180 days can be allowed to conclude a trial. Impeachment requires a 2/3 vote in the Chamber of Deputies, but of the 513 seats, the opposition has 199. Therefore, 145 members of her own coalition would have to vote to impeach. Given the current climate (the zika virus, a worsening economy, the corruption scandal with Petrobras), an impeachment can certainly occur, just not in the next 7 weeks.

Brazil Petrobras former director Jorge Zelada jailed
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-35467529 This sentencing is in itself what was to have been expected. The story, however, makes two curious claims:
1) "President Dilma Rousseff, who chaired Petrobras when much of the corruption is believed to have taken place, has been cleared of involvement."
With an ongoing investigation, how can such a statement be made?
2) "Petrobras' investments alone represent 2% of Brazil's gross national product"
Just intuitively I feel this estimate is far too low, or that GDP is not the proper measure. From an "originating" Petrobas transaction, to where that real ends up at the end of the period, has just got to comprise far more than 2% of the transactional value. I'm not sure if I have the proper term or not, but it seems the fungibility (?) of money is getting in the way of a proper analysis here. It's what % of GDP that has as its originating engine a Petrobas transaction that should be the focus, not just the originating transactions themselves. In short, if you take Petrobas out of that economy, that economy will drop far, far more than 2%.

Brazilian Vice-President Michel Temer (PMDB) has all but given up on impeachment.  He said he wanted to work with the president on the economy. He intends to run for president. His new approach positions him as the man on the steed out to save the economy to gain pedigree in the next election. If the economy fails, President Rousseff takes the blame as Vice-President Temer is not the leader but one who advised the president, the opposition. If the economy gains, he could tell voters it was due to his suggestions and fought for his interest groups. This is a fine balance, his supporters could view him as the opposition's lap dog if the economy continues to falter and his interest groups are unattended.  But that is another forecast. He will not impeach during an economic slowdown unless there is another scandal that forces the president to go from office.

Rousseff’s opponents within her main coalition partner, the fractious Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB), are losing hope that they can impeach the leftist leader and replace her with their man, Vice President Michel Temer. " . . .  in recent weeks, a growing consensus has emerged in Brazil’s political establishment that the evidence against Rousseff is too flimsy to justify impeachment.  Her government is confident it has more than the one third of votes she needs in each chamber to block impeachment. “The momentum for impeachment has lost force, yes, due to the brutal interference of the Supreme Court in a legislative matter,” . . .  "Rousseff’s fiercest critics inside the PMDB are now focusing their efforts on a party convention in March, where they will push to leave the ruling coalition. They hope that will bring her government down just over a year into her second term. " . . .  anti-government demonstrations since the start of impeachment proceedings last month have so far failed to match the scale of protests in 2013 and early last year, that drew hundreds of thousands onto the streets.

I am from Brazil, and have been accompanying this process very closely. It is virtually impossible that it will happen in this time frame. The regular impeachment process would require approval by 2/3 of the chamber of deputies and 2/3 of the congress after a very long investigation conducted by a group of people elected by the political parties in these government houses. The Federal Supreme Court has established rules that difficult the process even more, decreasing the likelihood of its success. Finally, there still needs to appear a scandal involving the president that will be strong enough to draw popular attention and force her to resign.

Impeachment Steps are: 1) impeachment request, 2) form impeachment committee, 3) President has 10 sessions to present case, 4) committee has 5 sessions to prepare report, 5) committee reports decision to full chamber, 6) 2/3 vote in lower house required, 7) Senate convenes a trial, 8) Impeachment if 2/3 vote of Senate; Step 1 is complete, but step 2 must be redone per the Supreme Court. Not back in session until February 1. Also, In another positive sign for Rousseff, the Supreme Court also ruled that the Senate can review the grounds for impeachment, even if the lower house votes to impeach her, through a simple majority.

I'm jumping in halfway through - now that a whole bunch of questions have closed I should have cognitive space to follow up on this one over the next three months.
There have been many good comments on this issue since it opened, so I won't repeat them here. For me, the key points against impeachment are 
1. Brazil's economy is in a mess and a sane politician would rather not take over at this time.
2. With the high profile Olympics this year, political upheavals would be bad for Brazil's international image.
3. The Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, now one of Roussef's key opponents, is facing grave legal problems himself, which reduces his credibility.
4. It is very unlikely that one third of the Chamber won't support her against a motion calling for legal proceedings, given the number of seats her party currently holds. So far nothing has been made public that would weaken her standing within the party.
5. It looks like no further proceedings will happen on this matter until March, which gets too close to the deadline.
6. She won't go quietly and is likely to fight all the way to the end if necessary.

http://www.wsj.com/articles/brazilian-government-repays-14-billion-to-state-banks-1451513127 BRASÍLIA—Brazil’s government on Wednesday said it repaid $14 billion advanced to it by state-controlled institutions, effectively erasing controversial public financing operations that are at the heart of impeachment proceedings pending against President Dilma Rousseff.  The move, observers say, could take some political pressure off Ms. Rousseff and her administration, which have been accused by her opponents of using the operations to hide the severity of the country’s widening budget gap. Interim Treasury Chief Otavio Lacerda de Medeiros told reporters on Wednesday that from the administration’s standpoint, all disputed practices have been cleaned up. “Everything has been paid,” he said. House Speaker Eduardo Cunha. . .  said Tuesday that paying down the debt wouldn’t alter the impeachment process.
. . . 
The institutions are supposed to be paid back by the treasury at the end of every month. But the government has failed to repay the banks in a timely fashion, according to Brazil’s public-accounting court TCU. The court ruled this year that the delayed repayments amounted to loans from state banks to the government to finance public spending, something banned by Brazilian law. Earlier this month, the TCU said all payments should be made by year-end.  Opposition politicians seized on the TCU’s ruling as grounds to launch impeachment proceedings against Ms. Rousseff this month.

Dec 29: "Brazil's House to decide on impeachment by end-March: speaker" --> http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-brazil-rousseff-cunha-idUKKBN0UC16Q20151229 Brazil's lower house of Congress will likely decide by March on whether to recommend the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff, House Speaker Eduardo Cunha said on Tuesday. Cunha, a bitter political foe of the embattled president, said he also plans to appeal recent Supreme Court decisions that raised Rousseff's prospects for blocking the impeachment process. Rousseff's opponents filed an impeachment request on the grounds she allegedly broke budget laws. The Rousseff-Cunha standoff has stalled legislation seen by investors as necessary to shore up investor confidence as Brazil's budget deficit balloons amid a deep recession. Cunha's position was weakened by Supreme Court decisions earlier this month. The justices voted to give the Senate authority to review the grounds for Rousseff's impeachment even if the lower house votes to recommend her impeachment. The justices also ruled against a lower house ballot that stacked an impeachment committee with Rousseff opponents. Cunha, who faces his own charges for alleged involvement in a giant corruption scandal involving state-owned oil company Petrobras, said the Senate is unlikely to block Rousseff's impeachment if the lower house approves it with the required two-third majority. Many analysts think Rousseff can muster the 171 lower house votes needed to quash the impeachment proceedings, but Cunha said that would not be tantamount to a sweeping political success.

Given that the Brazilian Congress has decided to take a recess until 1 February 2016, despite the urgency inherent to any impeachment process, it is highly unlikely that there will be a final decision on the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff before 1 April 2016. Add to the fact that a recent decision by the Brazilian Supreme Court has stalled the process even further since the political moves of Ms Rousseff's greatest foe and President of the Brazilian Lower House of Congress, Eduardo Cunha, were found illegal, thus calling for another vote on the committee responsible for analyzing the impeachment request. As to the possibility of Ms Rousseff resigning from office, past experience has shown that it is not in her nature to give in to political pressure, let alone own up to any wrongdoings or shortcomings relating to herself or any of her underlings, thereby warranting the conclusion of a slim chance of resignation. On the other hand, the nomination of Mr Nelson Barbosa as Finance Minister signals more of the same, i.e., that Ms Rousseff is back at the helm of economic decisions, which has already met with a backlash from the financial markets, and may add to the outcry of the Brazilian population, whose disapproval of the current administration is at 67% of the general population according to Datafolha. This could mean that more people are likely to throng to the streets in the coming months so as to make Ms Rousseff reconsider her position as head of State, which justifies a slight 5% chance of resignation before 1 April 2016.

http://www.voanews.com/content/court-rulings-could-help-brazil-rousseff-escape-impeachment/3108356.html This adds a very interesting twist. What happens if the lower house passes an impeachment resolution and the Senate, rather than conducting a trial, "reviews the grounds" and rejects the resolution. Was this court decision speaking only to her remaining in office until the Senate decides whether to take up the case, or does the court decision turn the resolution of the lower house into a mere "recommendation," and now the Senate decision whether to take up the case is the signal marker of impeachment. The insertion of the Senate into the middle of the process, getting two votes on the same issue (the first of which is bound to be politically biased) seems highly unusual as compared to the logic of the U.S. impeachment process. So long as Good Judgment doesn't change the stipulated criteria, it won't matter to us, But it does change the process a lot.

Rousseff’s ruling coalition controls a significant majority in the legislature. also from http://www.thestar.com/news/world/2015/12/08/brazils-impeachment-process-against-president-dilma-rouseff-explained.html The proceedings are long, tedious and complex, and will likely last at least several weeks. But, essentially there are three main phases:
a) A congressional committee spends a few weeks investigating the president’s alleged corruption. Rousseff has several chances to respond to those allegations and defend herself. Then the committee votes. A simple majority (more than 50 per cent) in favour of impeachment means we move to phase b).
b) The lower house of Brazil’s Congress looks at what the committee has come up with and takes a vote. If two-thirds of this house votes for impeachment, we move to phase c), and Rousseff must take a leave of absence.
c) The upper house, the Senate, also takes a vote. Again, two-thirds of senators need to vote for impeachment for it to happen. The lawyer who initiated Brazil's last impeachment of a president, in 1992, on Sunday attacked what he said was the politicized and unfair push to impeach President Dilma Rousseff today. Marcello Lavenere, now 77, was an attorney and president of the Brazilian Bar Association when he co-authored a petition for impeachment of then-president Fernando Collor de Mello on grounds that Collor benefited from an influence peddling scheme. ... "Dilma has the right to say that this was not a crisis caused by irregular behavior on her behalf," he said. Lavenere said that in contrast, back in 1992, "the president of the republic himself was the one accused of committing illegal acts." He also said that Collor was given ample opportunities to clear himself before the accusations were transformed into an impeachment procedure, whereas today "a position has been taken against Dilma before any judgement." "Impeachment is not for political fights," he said. "What did she do? Did she rob? Did she take a bribe? Did she receive illicit gains? Did she violate the decorum of her post? Did she commit any of the illicit acts contained in the constitution and the law of impeachment? No." http://www.france24.com/en/20151206-author-brazils-last-presidential-impeachment-defends-rousseff

Below is a good summary of the process. My understanding is that 34 requests for impeachment have been submitted to the lower house, and they have finally announced that they will "accept" one of them, which I presume means that they will now move to have formal proceedings on the issue of whether an impeachment should be issued. (In fact, it sounds like those proceedings began with the long reading of the request.)  Now a committee will make a report and the plenary (the entire lower house?) will vote on whether to issue the impeachment or not. In the mean time Rousseff is filing anything she can think of with the courts to stop the train. A couple of guesses: 1. I don't think this is a timing issue. I think we'll either see an impeachment or see the proceedings stopped before April 1. The only way it drags on longer is if the courts intervene to stop the process, but if Brazil has anything like our concept of separation of powers the courts will be reluctant to do so. Probability of delay beyond April 1: 10% 2. I don't know that much about Brazilian politics, bur I don't think that the lower chamber would have accepted the request unless they though there was a pretty good chance of getting an impeachment from the plenary vote. (All that advice about not missing when you try to kill the king and whatnot.) Probability of the votes for impeachment being there: 80% 3. Given the mandatory step-down in the case of impeachment, I don't see her resigning prior to impeachment.  I'm going with 80%. From Bloomberg:  "The lower house president on Wednesday evening announced his decision to accept one of the 34 the requests to impeach the president on charges that range from illegally financing her re-election to doctoring fiscal accounts this year and last. 
 . . .  "In a sign of how long and complicated the impeachment process could prove, lower house secretary and Congressman Beto Mansur spent more than three hours on the floor Thursday afternoon reading out-loud the entire impeachment request. Lawmakers say the reading is a formality required by law. "After the lower house committee makes its recommendation, the plenary will vote on impeachment. If two-thirds of the deputies back impeachment, hearings would begin in the Senate. In that case, Rousseff would have to step down and hand over the reins to Vice President Michel Temer during the deliberations. He would remain in power if the Senate impeaches Rousseff or step aside if she is absolved. The process may last up to 180 days. http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-03/rousseff-turns-to-brazil-supreme-court-to-snuff-out-impeachment

* The committee’s recommendation goes to the house floor for a vote. If impeachment is backed by two-thirds of the house, or 342 lawmakers, official impeachment hearings will then move to the Senate,

COMMENT:   It appears to me that this question hinges on several issues: 1)  time.  How long does this process take?  Thanks to z0k's post Dec 2, 2015 12:47PM, and the NYT article quoted above, it sounds like realistically the committee won't have a report until after New Years, and possibly much later (or never) if there is a Supreme Court injunction.  While it is theoretically possible  that impeachment may be initiated in the time-frame of this question, I think that a Supreme Court action that will freeze everything is likely, so the odds are low that it moves fast enough.  (Question:  how does something end up in the Supreme Court's docket?  Is there a vote?  What is the threshold to send something to the Supreme Court?) 2) merits.  Incompetence is not an impeachable offense.  Has she done anything that is?   This question involves the Supreme Court.  More delays. I assume that the Supreme Court has been stacked by Rousseff, so I consider the odds low that the Supreme Court will rule against her.   3)  politics.  It comes down to a vote that requires 2/3rds to pass.  Does she have the 1/3 + 1 votes to block it?    She appears to at this time . .  . but how much might her support erode during this process????  On the slim chance that it gets to this point in the time-frame of this question, I give only even odds that she'd survive the vote.

'But the political situation is so volatile that things could easily change a few weeks from now,' Mr. Sallum added. Before Congress goes into recess, a committee in the lower house would need to be formed to examine the impeachment request and decide whether it should advance. Then legislators would be expected to go through various procedural hurdles. Given the narrow time window, political analysts say it is unlikely that the lower house of Congress could act decisively on impeachment proceedings before its recess unless special sessions are convened. And before an impeachment vote could take place, legislators in Ms. Rousseff’s Workers Party have vowed to seek a Supreme Court injunction blocking the entire process." http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/03/world/americas/brazil-president-faces-prospect-of-impeachment.html

Rousseff's Workers Party decided not to support Eduardo Cunha in the current ousting process against him, to which he reacted by allowing the impeachment proceedings to start, contrary to the expectations that they would "help" each other with their "problems".
There are now two points that lead to the answer of this question. The first is: "Is there enough time before 1 April 2016?"
As I see it, the answer is "Barely." The congressmen in Brazil go into recess by the end of December and return only by the beginning of February. There are a lot of steps to go, involving two reports by the special comission of the Chamber of Deputies, two votes by the Chamber as a whole, ratifying the accusation and a judgement by the Senate, each with it's own term. The opposition is moving, trying to get the Chamber to vote in January, but it is unlikely that they will succeed.
The second question is the outcome of the votes. And that depends strongly on the popular support to the impeachment process, which by now is unpredictable. There are distinct sectors of the population supporting each side, and the final outcome may depend on a crucial fact, such as a piece of evidence appearing against Rousseff, or a public outcry after a confrontation results in a death on one of the sides.
I'd say that the chance that she will be eventually impeached is around 30% - 40%, while the chance that she is by April 1st is much lower.

e.g. Bill Clinton was impeached but acquitted. The news-reports are correct about the process, but impeachment is just the next step. Here's a link to an English version of Brazil's constitution:
http://english.tse.jus.br/arquivos/federal-constitution Article 86. If charges against the President of the Republic are accepted by two-thirds of the Chamber of Deputies, he shall be submitted to trial before the Supreme Federal Court for common criminal offenses or before the Federal Senate for crimes of malversation.
Paragraph 1. The President shall be suspended from his functions:
I – in common criminal offenses, if the accusation or the complaint is received by the Federal Supreme Court;
II – in the event of crimes of malversation, after the proceeding is instituted by the Federal Senate. Paragraph 2. If, after a period of one hundred and eighty days, the trial has not been concluded, the suspension of the President shall cease without prejudice to the normal progress of the proceeding. The term "impeachment" is not mentioned, but we can assume that Rousseff being "submitted to trial" would qualify as impeachment. So, I'm raising the odds. A special committee of the Chamber of Deputies was constituted on September 3, 1992 to study the impeachment petition. On September 24, 1992, the committee voted (32 votes in favour, one vote against, one abstention) to approve a report accepting the impeachment petition and recommending that the full Chamber of Deputies should accept the charges of impeachment. Under the Constitution of Brazil, the impeachment process would only proceed if two thirds of the Chamber of Deputies voted to allow the charges of impeachment to be presented to the Senate. On September 29, 1992, Collor was impeached by the Chamber of Deputies, with more than two thirds of its members concurring. In the decisive roll call vote, 441 deputies voted for and 38 deputies voted against the admission of the charges of impeachment."

A GOOD SUMMARY OF THE SITUATION:
http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/article42134757.html#storylink=cpy "It would be bad enough if Brazil’s embattled president, Dilma Rousseff, just had a recession and a plummeting currency to deal with. But in a perfect storm, she also has two corruption investigations, a fractious Congress and impeachment threats on her plate. "Inflation is running at nearly 10 percent, there is a soaring budget deficit and the value of the real has fallen by 32 percent. Average wages are declining and unemployment in Brazil’s six major metropolitan regions was 7.6 percent in September after years of almost full employment. And the bad news keeps on coming: In the first nine months of this year, 657,761 jobs were lost, and 1.5 million jobs are expected to disappear from Brazil’s formal economy in 2015. . . . Standard & Poor’s has downgraded Brazil’s credit rating to junk status, and Fitch Ratings downgraded Brazil to BBB-, which places it at just a notch above junk. Corruption investigations into both Petrobras, the state-run oil company, and the construction industry already have damaged investor confidence. Dozens of members of Congress are under investigation and important corporate leaders have been jailed.  . . . the Brazilian economy is expected to shrink by 3 percent this year and by an estimated 2.1 percent in 2016 . . .  Brazil hasn’t had such a dramatic economic contraction since the 1930s . . . . "In October 2014, Rousseff was narrowly elected to her second term after a year of protests over everything from corruption, bus fare increases, poor public health services and education, to the high cost of preparing for the 2014 World Cup. Still, “it’s unusual to have a reelection and then so quickly be under an impeachment threat,” said Eric Farnsworth, vice president of the Council of the Americas.
. . . 
"Rousseff won’t be able to finish her term “in a traditional way,” said Joel Velasco, senior vice president at Albright Stonebridge Group, a Washington strategic advisory firm. “It’s become more real every day. This government has failed; its policies have failed.” "He said there are four possible scenarios: ▪ The 2014 election could be declared void if it is found that the Rousseff ticket used bribes to finance the campaign. This is the most unlikely scenario, Velasco said. An investigation into 2014 campaign donations is ongoing. ▪ Rousseff might be impeached if it is found she used accounting tricks to lessen the severity of budget deficits. ▪ She could quit, but Rousseff has said she has “never considered resigning.” Even respected former President Fernando Henrique Cardoso has suggested she resign or issue a frank apology for her mistakes. ▪ Rousseff could muddle through, presiding over a “government that is rudderless.” That’s the most likely scenario, according to Velasco. If that’s the case, Rousseff needs to build consensus and assemble a kitchen cabinet of experts regardless of political party, he said. "The most serious impeachment threat to date comes from a group of high-profile lawyers who say she manipulated budget accounts to hide the seriousness of budget deficits in 2014 and 2015, but there is a legal question whether she could be impeached over something that allegedly occurred during her previous term. "Nearly two dozen impeachment requests have been filed, but the latest is not only supported by Brazil’s largest opposition party, the Brazilian Social Democracy Party, but also was submitted by former Justice Minister Miguel Reale Jr. and respected lawyer Hélio Bicudo, one of the pioneers of Rousseff’s Workers Party. . . . It falls to the president of the lower house, Eduardo Cunha — who himself is under investigation .  . — to decide whether to accept the request. "If the lower house decides to accept an impeachment petition, it is put to a vote. It requires a two-thirds majority to send the petition to the Senate for a trial. Rousseff supporters say she now has enough votes from her coalition to stave off impeachment. " . . . Cunha might not be in any hurry to push for Rousseff’s impeachment. While the impeachment threat simmers, he remains politically relevant despite his own problems. “The fox guarding the hen house doesn’t want to kill the chicken,” said Velasco. . . .  there is no love lost between the two [Cunha & Rousseff]. "Paulo Sotero, director of the Brazil Institute at the Woodrow Wilson International Center, said he expects Cunha will be expelled from Congress in the next few months. The Cunha affair must be dealt with before there is any move on impeachment, said Sotero . . . . "An impeachment is not without precedent in Brazil. My baseline estimate of likelihood of the event in question -- a president of a republic where president is independent of legislature getting impeached, removed or run out of office  before his/her term ended -- is 3% (30 - Ballpark number of all such events), 960 - appx number of complete presidential terms in which event could have occurred).  One would think the fact that Brazil was one of the few countries where the event  has occurred before --President Fernando Collor De mello was forced from office in 1992 -- should up the odds of it happening again, but i don't know if that is so or if so by how much.  And at least three conditions present at to Collor's ouster would likely have to also be met for Dilma to meet the same fate: 1. He was directly implicated in the scandal. 
2. Congress broadly supported his impeachment. 
3. There were big street protests demanding his resignation. #2 would seem to hinge on #1. As for #3, Popular disapproval of Dilma has yet to be expressed through street protests of any magnitude.  Repeat of the June 2014 street protest would probably require international attention to be focused on Brazil as during the Copa des Americas in the run up to the world cup  and for students to be on break, but the Olympics won't begin, and students won't be out (i think)  until well after April 1.

Great research and discussion on this question, especially by the earlier respondents - thanks! Given Rousseff's background and personality I think that it is unlikely that she will resign.    There seems to be sufficient cause for impeachment on the issue of fiddling the books and so pressing on with social program expenditures prior to the 2014 election which she narrowly won.   However, I believe that the other political parties would probably prefer to see her flounder on and her party (the PT) lose the next election.  If she is impeached the VP Michel Temer (PMDB) would become president and have to try to govern with presumably little support from the PT and a worsening economy and continuing corruption revelations - not attractive.    The other significant party (PSDB) whose candidate Aecio Neves was the runner-up for the presidency in 2014 would probably also prefer to mount their next campaign for the 2018 presidency against the backdrop of an increasingly discredited Roussef government. There is an outside chance that the PSDB might press and find support to have the 2014 election result set aside because of the accounting irregularities in the national accounts.    This would trigger a new election in 2016 that the PSDB would hope to win, launch some radically different (more conservative) economic policies and hope to ride an early wave of optimism with new gov't, new policies, and Olympic Games.

http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-brazil-courts-boost-impeachment-push-but-dilma-rousseff-s-ouster-still-distant-2132957 Oct 8. " . . .Rousseff's opponents have a clearer path to impeach her after two court rulings against her this week but political hurdles still make her ouster unlikely anytime soon. "Some opposition lawmakers are wary of moving against a democratically-elected president without more convincing evidence that she broke the law, and business leaders argue that impeachment would prompt even further political and economic uncertainty, causing more problems than it fixes. "For now, Rousseff appears to have more than enough votes to defeat impeachment. Complex procedural and political obstacles remain for any petition to succeed. For starters, backers of impeachment must build momentum with the notoriously fractious and unwieldy political blocs in Congress. Finding consensus among those jockeying for power in possible coalitions that would take shape in a new government could be even more difficult. "It will not be easy to find the support you need to start the proceedings or map out a scenario for power beyond that," says Rafael Cortez, a political analyst at Tendencias, a consulting firm in Sao Paulo. Congress must still decide whether to act on the audit court's decision, formally censuring Rousseff and rejecting the government's 2014 books. "Senator Eunicio Oliveira, a leader of Brazil's largest party, the PMDB, told Reuters that Congress would not get around to voting on whether Rousseff had broken the budget law before March. And the lower house speaker said a bicameral budget committee was unlikely to study the matter in 2015.
. . .
" . . . At present, Rousseff could still count on about 220 of the 513 members in the lower house of Congress, enough to block any vote needed to start impeachment proceedings, according to Brasilia consultants Barral M Jorge Consultores Associados. "Under Brazil's constitution, impeachment requests are weighed by the lower house of Congress, which must approve any petition with a two-thirds majority to launch a trial in the Senate. The Senate would have 180 days to conduct a trial, presided by the head of the Supreme Court, and would need a two-thirds majority to impeach.  . . .  "But the success of any petition depends on support from the centrist PSDB party, Rousseff's main opposition, and the PMDB, a centre-right party that is her main coalition partner, albeit an increasingly demanding and rebellious one. They have both been unable to speak with a unified voice on the possibility of impeachment, primarily because rival blocs within each party are perceived to be angling as much against each other as they are against Rousseff. "Neither party relishes the idea of taking over a government in crisis or having to implement unpopular austerity measures that economists say are needed to restore public finances so shaky that ratings agency Standard & Poor's last month downgraded Brazil's debt to junk status.  . . .  "Rousseff supporters could still seek to thwart any trial through the courts, particularly by challenging technicalities. Already, they point to a constitutional provision, written before Brazil amended its constitution to enable re-election, that says impeachments must try wrongdoing conducted during the existing term. Because the ongoing petitions cite episodes from her first term, they argue, they are unconstitutional.

COMMENT:  I think that we are beginning to see a gathering storm.

Again using my 100-point log-2 scale, I'm assessing Dilma's very real gestures (and politically expensive concessions re:appointments to second-tier offices) towards Cunha as a -3. Probabilities might change sharply until Tuesday; we're on an extended holiday, and Cunha might either expedite the process significantly in the mean-time (a 25-30 points-grade shift) or silently continue to negotiate his position (which includes Dilma's grasp on the Supreme Court that ought to authorise criminal investigations on him), which should bring something between -2 to -10 points in the log 2 scale.
Raise above crowd so I don't look stupid if this pops.

Her position has weakened considerably in the past few days,  and her own evaluation of the situation, according to political gossip sources that have often been unambiguously correct months in advance, has been leading her to despondency. Even Supreme Court justices who were widely considered to be partisan have been making decisions and statements contrary to her. The distribution of my own probability estimate about this has always been very bimodal -- there are clusters of possible worlds where it happens and where it doesn't. The politics around this work a lot like a cusp catastrophe; parties, ideologies and institutions are very weak, and the relevant actors bet on hopefully self-fulfilling prophecies. But as time passes and moves are made, we're closed to the control parameter singularity where one of those attractors vanishes. My modal estimates that were around 5% (the institutional solution where the rats-fleeing-the-sinking-ship doesn't dominate the dynamics, but rather her electoral and fiscal fraud issues get her) and 60% (the scenario where politics abandons her); but after some months of arrogance and inactivity towards buying off the political class, we've had quite some log-rolling, which dials the latter scenario down; but her grip on the institutional processes (specially the courts) has weakened so the former scenario gets dialled up. Pro pundit tip: it's near impossible to decode Cunha (and the latter, political landslide process) Watch federal prosecutor (rough approximation of his role) Rodrigo Janot instead, who's a bellwether for how the whole institutional scenario might turn out.

President Dilma Rousseff has suffered several losses in a short period of time...
(a) she has been defeated in Congress in many of her proposals to reform the economy.
(b) she is the target of an investigation by the TSE (top electoral authority). The TSE is looking into irregularities in President Dilma Rousseff's re-election campaign last year. (c)  the 2014 spending accounts for Rousseff's government was not approved by the TCU due to several irregularities in the accounts – and the last time that happen was in 1937! Note: the TCU is equivalent to the U.S. Government Accountability Office – GAO. 
(d) Rousseff shrank her cabinet and reshuffled ministers on last week (October 2nd) to bolster alliances within her coalition government and block efforts to impeach her. However, that alliance has proven to be ineffective so far and did not strengthen her coalition's ties to lawmakers needed to help re-balance public finances.

https://www.stratfor.com/analysis/brazil-risk-impeachment-looms-large Sept 16.  "The ongoing corruption scandal at state-owned energy firm Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, could pose a real political risk to Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff, particularly as Brazil's economic conditions worsen.  . . .  "However, the most immediate risk comes from other parties. As the political power of the Workers' Party deteriorates, other parties are likely to continue pushing for the president's impeachment over the next few months for their own benefit. Impeachment is unlikely at this point; the process is lengthy and depends greatly on the votes of individual congressmen and evidence uncovered by investigations.   "The ruling party's political opponents, such as members of the Brazilian Social Democracy Party, have for months attempted to build public support for impeachment proceedings, but they have lacked the votes in Brazil's two-house Congress to open them. However, during the past several months, investigations against the government have advanced to the point where decisions could occur within months, thereby providing the opposition with a catalyst to again begin seeking a vote to open impeachment proceedings. "Two investigations at separate federal courts in particular could pose a risk to Rousseff's rule. One is at the Federal Court of Accounts, Brazil's highest tribunal dealing with government accountability matters, and concerns alleged fiscal irregularities for the central government from 2012-2014. The second is at an electoral court and concerns illegal donations allegedly made to Rousseff's campaign in 2014 that were obtained by overcharging Petrobras. In a worst-case scenario, the second investigation could result in the electoral court voting to annul the 2014 election — a decision that, if the government appeals and loses, would end with the resignation of president and vice president and the head of the lower house of Congress becoming president until new elections can be held 90 days after the impeachment. The Federal Court of Accounts is slated to deliver its final opinion by mid-October. "The case being heard before the Federal Court of Accounts alleges that the central government made irregular payments to state entities and did not follow existing regulations in crafting the country's annual budget on several occasions. If the government is found to have violated the law, the opposition parties could have a pretext to attempt to open a vote on impeachment proceedings in the lower house of Congress. The opposition can use public ire over Brazil's economy and the Petrobras scandal to gain support. ""The wild card in such a vote is the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party. The party is the largest in the senate and the second largest in the lower house, and for years its legislative heft has helped the Workers' Party pass legislation. The president of the lower house is the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party's Eduardo Cunha, who was allied with the Workers' Party until July when he broke away. Because Cunha faces criminal charges stemming from the Petrobras scandal regardless of whether the Workers' Party is in charge, he could either choose to accept or deny an opposition request for a vote on impeachment. If the opposition chooses to use a Federal Court of Accounts decision to attempt to open impeachment proceedings, it can circumvent Cunha by presenting a request to the lower house floor and hoping for a simple majority win with the votes of 257 or more congressmen. However, to open a proceeding and secure an impeachment through the lower house, legislators from the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party would have to defect to the opposition. "The party has, so far, remained loyal to Rousseff. However, its priorities clearly diverge from those of the Workers' Party.  . . . it may be in the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party's interest to split from the Workers' Party despite public promises of cooperation.  . . . The parties that want to impeach the president have only 113 seats and would need at least 144 more votes to open proceedings. Consequently, defections from the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party or even from the Workers' Party are necessary to make impeachment a realistic threat. ". . .  the president's persistent low approval ratings and the risk of removal for both the president and vice president because of an electoral court decision likely influenced the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party's calculations and led it to prepare for the worst. "Members of the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party and the Brazilian Social Democracy Party have met to discuss possible options for a coalition government if the president is impeached. For example, recent discussions on the matter resulted in the Brazilian Social Democracy Party's attempt to extract a promise from Vice President Michel Temer not to run for president in 2018 in exchange for the party's support after a Rousseff impeachment. The Brazilian Democratic Movement Party and Brazilian Social Democracy Party are far from united on the issue of a future alliance; some members of both parties oppose the plan. But the fact that such discussions are taking place suggests that both sides consider impeachment proceedings plausible and seek to take advantage of them. "Though a presidential impeachment is far from certain, Brazil's opposition is leaning toward opening the proceedings to safeguard its political future. Over the next few months, Rousseff likely will reshuffle her Cabinet to include representatives of the Workers' Party and Brazilian Democratic Movement Party factions. This could secure the necessary votes in the lower house to deter a vote to begin impeachment. Meanwhile, the pro-impeachment camp will make its own moves to guarantee that it can begin proceedings once the Federal Court of Accounts issues a legal opinion.
~~~~~~~

President Dilma Rousseff announced Oct. 2 that she will reduce the number of government ministries and replace several Cabinet members, G1 reported. The president will eliminate eight of the current 39 ministries and replace the chief of staff and ministers in nine departments: defense, communication, ports, health, education, human rights, labor, sciences and technology, and the secretariat of the presidency. In addition, Rousseff says she will cut ministry spending by 30 percent. Rousseff replaced eight ministers with members of the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party (PMDB). Prior to the announcement, Brazilian media speculated Rousseff would allocate six to seven ministry head positions to the PMDB, which is her own Workers' Party's primary ally in the legislature.

Impeachment is 80% likely before April 1, 2016.   Dilma is losing popular support.  Her actions to reduce Ministries and reduce salaries for Ministers will erode Congressional support. Two new requests for impeachment were filed on Oct 1, and her support in Congress appears to be eroding. The Real is overvalued, and the economy is overdue for a correction.  GDP is contracting 2.6%, Inflation is at 9.5%.   Dilma has broken with the relatively orthodox policies of her predecessor Lula. Dilma has not at this time been accused of a crime.   She would not be subject to impeachment for crimes committed prior to her presidency (when she was a minister in Lula's government for example.) Brazilians have become accustomed to strong economic growth.   Dilma may be able to evade direct responsibility for the Petrobras scandal, but the protests are less about the scandal and more about the overall economic climate (in my opinion).

There is no way that Rouseff will resign. She and her prededecessor  "Lula" were the first PT or Workers party Candidates to be elected. Social programs lke La Bolsa Familia  pay low income famlies to send and keep their childern in school. As a result, over the long run, Brazil will have eliminated illiteracy and brought health care to many millions who had none. Although Rouseff's approval ratings have gome down to 10% no rival poltical party seems to have the votes or incentive to bring an impeachmnet resulution. The Speaker of the Assembly and President of the Senate are both subject to bribery charges in  connection with the Petrobras scandal  and there is a 60% chance that each of those opponents will face separate impeachment proceedings, a 100% chance that one of those power brokers will be impeached. Plus the Vice Predident who would succeed under the constitution is from the PDMB, Rousseff and her  PT party's former coalition partner. Proof, Rouseff's veto of approximately 18 of 23 spending bills,was sustained and her opponents could not summon the 2/3 vote required to overcome veto. "When the PT was strong, the majority of these parties were happy to partner with the government. Now with Ms Rousseff on the rack, they are deserting a sinking ship, claim opposition leaders." "The petition accuses her of fiddling the public accounts to produce politically acceptable budget balances. The TCU, the government accounts watchdog, has criticised these so-called accounting tricks. It is expected to vote on whether to reject the accounts as early as next month.  . . . "Mr Sampaio believes he has the 257 votes needed to get an impeachment process started. The next milestone would be a lower house vote requesting the senate to begin the formal “trial” of the president. Mr Sampaio and his allies would need a two-thirds majority, or 342 seats, to get this through. “The headlines in the newspapers and on television will be: ‘The impeachment process starts against Dilma.’ After that, no one will be able to stop it, between the pressure from the population and from politics, we are confident it will be feasible,” says Mr Sampaio. "A key debate in congress, however, will be how much an impeachment should be guided by legal factors and how much by politics. Mr Sampaio argues it is 90 per cent political. The fact the TCU has already identified irregularities in the public accounts is enough, he says, without any formal charges being levelled against the president. Constitutional law experts agree. If congress wants to impeach a president, it can. The only president to face an impeachment since Brazil returned to democracy from military dictatorship in 1984, Fernando Collor, was accused of corruption but never convicted.
. . . 
"Many lawmakers believe the president has committed enough mistakes to warrant a leadership challenge.  . . . "Politically, Ms Rousseff has erred too, her critics say. At the start of her second term, she alienated the PT’s coalition ally, the PMDB, a loose grouping of regional politicians more inspired by pork than ideology, by not sharing more power.
